+Perma Frost Oh I completely agree on being private. At the time, even me, 
who can't stand Lea, was shocked by how many "fans" sort of demanded her in

not be true, but it's sick to somehow wish she was), calling his phone to 
hear his answering machine, and creating theories about how she found out 
and how she was just...out of her mind. I'm not saying anyone *here* did 
that, btw. But back then, on tumblr at least, some Monchele fans were just 
out of line and cursing other Glee co-stars as well because they had get 
togethers and such (not just the memorial) and were smiling at some 
photos... from personal experience, I can tell, it is perfectly fine to be 
smiling,  it can take days for someone to finally accept it and no denial 
in the world is enough.

but I could never wish anyone that kind of pain, it's good that she's 
moving on. My opinion about her milking Cory's death has nothing to do with 
it...

top_comment.text:
Ellen didn't start mentioning "Cory" for what seemed like the longest time 
in this segment that I thought they were going to go through this entire 
interview without saying his name. When she finally did, and of course she 
had to, it was "Cory's passing". I held my breath when she said that, then 
the camera panned to Lea and it showed her holding back... And I thought my 
heart break a little. It struck me then, that she isn't brave, she isn't 
strong, she isn't a goddess of all things nice; She is just a normal girl 
trying to keep it together as best as she could after the loss of her 
lover. She is positive about this because she has to.

I love how they talk about Cory once they got the white elephant out of the 
way. Ah, the fond memories. That truly is the best way to keep the departed 
in the world. Ellen is quite fond of Cory, I think, but she never really 
talked about him when she interviewed the many Glee stars that came on her 
show during this period. I'm glad she saved that part for Lea.

I haven't realize this until now - Lea and Cory were the sweetest couple 
because both of them genuinely were sweet, sweet people. 

To everyone who knew you, whether intimately or not, you brought them joy 
while you lived, Cory.﻿

pain that Cory's friends and family experienced both during his life and 
after his death. They will be asking what they could have done, what else 
they should have done to try and save him but there was nothing. It was his 
decision to begin taking drugs and to continue doing so. In that he put his 
own desires ahead of those who love him and fought for him. No matter what 
you may say about me and my opinions it can't alter the fact that he was 
selfish.

fault that he did. I feel sorry for those who are left behind bearing the 
burden of guilt that they shouldn't be feeling. If that offends you then 
it's tough. It doesn't alter the facts.

comments.text:
+solehin dixor I don't judge him from media reports and like me you know 
there's only one way to beat addiction. You have to WANT to stop more than 
you want to continue. Yes he entered re-hab twice but it's a matter of 
public record that he was ordered to do so as a condition of keeping his 
job. 

Cory was like many other addicts, he professed his desire to quit but that 
desire whether real or not never exceeded his desire to indulge. The people 
who loved him and supported him through it all were betrayed. Just as I 
betrayed my own family and friends by becoming an alcoholic. I haven't had 
a drink in 10 yrs, 4 months, 2 weeks and five days but I still don't feel 
"cured" nor do I feel I've truly earned their forgiveness. They've given it 
to me anyway and I love them all the more for it but whenever I crave a 
drink (every day) I remind myself of the price they paid while I was 
guzzling anything that would pour. Never again. 

Cory never made that decision, never accepted the responsibility for his 
own actions and while his death is sad it's not Cory who really pays the 
price for his selfishness. Those he left behind pay that every day and they 
don't deserve to. That's why I say and stand by my comment. Cory was weak, 
selfish and brought his death upon himself. He deserved the end he got 
because he simply didn't care as much about them as he did his next fix and 
drink. It's a harsh comment, I know that but it's also the truth.

comments.text:
+m13laball It's possible to drink without getting drunk, but drugs 
(especially certain highly addictive drugs) are trickier and it is better 
to skip them. But unless you have a religious or medical reason for not 
drinking, if you're in college why not have a drink and find out what it's 
like? Wait until you're 21 if that makes you more comfortable, but after 
school is finished you'll find that it's unusual for adults to not drink at 
all (if you're not mormon/muslim/pentecostal etc or ill, people will assume 
you have a drinking problem and are in recovery if you refuse all alcohol).

enjoy the taste of wine, beer, and cocktails.
